description: From Middle English tresour, from Old French tresor (“treasury”), from Latin thēsaurus (“treasure”), from Ancient Greek θησαυρός (thēsaurós, “treasure house”). Displaced native Old English goldhord. Doublet of thesaurus.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A collection of valuable things; accumulated wealth; a stock of money, jewels, etc.

examples: Ye shall be peculiar treasure unto me.

"Hello, Treasure," he said without turning round. For a second she hesitated, standing in the soft light of the lamp, the deep blue of the rug making a background for her, the black fur collar of her coat framing the vivid beauty of her face.

verbs.description: treasure (third-person singular simple present treasures, present participle treasuring, simple past and past participle treasured)

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a person or thing) To consider to be precious; to value highly.
examples: Oh, this ring is beautiful! I’ll treasure it forever.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To store or stow in a safe place.
examples: The rose-buds, withered as they were, were still treasured under his cuirass, and nearest to his heart.
